key_insight: The paper exposes a significant gap in spatial reasoning of MLLMs by moving evaluation beyond controlled indoor scenes to large-scale outdoor (open-world) scenarios with verifiable metric ground truth.
problem_solved: Existing benchmarks either simplify spatial tasks or are restricted to indoor domains, failing to diagnose how well MLLMs handle metric, large-scale, real-world spatial reasoning.
method: Construct a large-scale benchmark that includes outdoor/open-world scenes with verifiable metric ground truth and diverse spatial tasks (e.g., distance, orientation, localization).
Design evaluation protocols and metrics that measure metric accuracy, robustness across scales, and generalization from indoor to outdoor environments.
Systematically evaluate state-of-the-art MLLMs on the new benchmark to quantify the spatial reasoning gap and identify specific failure modes.
impact: Provides practitioners a realistic, quantitative way to evaluate and improve spatial intelligence in multimodal models, accelerating development of grounded, deployable AI for navigation, robotics, and AR/VR.
visual_elements: World map / outdoor scene collage annotated with metric ground-truth points and tasks (distance/arrows/angles).
Bar chart or radar plot comparing MLLM performance on indoor vs. outdoor spatial tasks to highlight the gap.
Task schematic icons (distance estimation, orientation, localization) with example input images and expected vs. predicted outputs.
Heatmap or error-distribution plot showing where and how model errors increase with scale or environmental complexity.
paper_title: From Indoor to Open World: Revealing the Spatial Reasoning Gap in MLLMs
paper_authors: Mingrui Wu, Zhaozhi Wang, Fangjinhua Wang, Jiaolong Yang, Marc Pollefeys
